text: so we use the black shoals martin model when we're pricing options you've heard that before all good now once we understand options a little bit more we come to find out that all of the assumptions in the bsm are not exactly correct one of which is how it integrates implied volatility into the pricing of options primarily how it assumes implied volatility so this video is going to talk about the implied volatility surface and the implied volatility smile so that anybody that trades options that's interested in the inner workings can have a better understanding on how premiums are actually calculated because they are not calculated in a textbook fashion as the black shoals model would assume so what's up everybody eric here welcome back to all the outliers and again we have a little more of a technical session here but i aim to make this video consumable we're going to keep it to less than 10 minutes but i'm hoping to share some useful information so that you can understand the underside of options a little more holistically so let's jump over and get to it so as i already mentioned the black shoals martin model it comes with a whole list of assumptions and not all of them are accurate one of which is the pricing of an underlying security and the reason why that matters is because it impacts how implied volatility is assumed to be so when we're talking about the bsm

text: volatility surface because it's taking in multiple inputs and it's giving you exactly this it's a surface profile where we can experience different implied volatilities for different series of options in the same expiration or different expirations the main punch line is it's not the same as the black scholes model would assume so i showed you that the call implied volatility was different than the put implied volatility for the same out of the money delta why that's because of the volatility smile so essentially on a vertical axis here we have implied volatility and then on the horizontal axis here we have um the strike price so whether it's in the money or out of the money and we're looking at puts here but essentially we see a little bit of a smile unless there's a skew in the smile or kurtosis which can occur but essentially what it means is that again the implied volatility for different series different strikes is not flat it's not equal we have at the money typically b seems to be lower implied volatility whereas deep out of the money or deep in the money tends to have increased implied volatility as you saw in that example i just showed you it's not always the case but very frequently is the case it is product specific so to recap because i got 10 minutes and 40 seconds i want to keep my promise overall the black shoals model in a vacuum assumes

text: you saw in that example i just showed you it's not always the case but very frequently is the case it is product specific so to recap because i got 10 minutes and 40 seconds i want to keep my promise overall the black shoals model in a vacuum assumes a log normal distribution which is the cumulative distribution of a log normal distribution that has certain series of assumptions that i showed to you are not the case so what that leaves us with is people that interact with the markets create implied volatility services for the individual securities that they're trading based on their series of assumptions to arrive at what they perceive to be the correct implied volatility for that product and that leads to different implied volatilities for various strikes within the same expiration and within different expirations so all of this is to say that the market at least that is of this point is pricing in different volatilities than the black shells model would assume and it is because the market does not move the way that the black shoals model assumes that it does we have fat tails we have more outlier cases than we would expect to see and that is exactly why the volatility surface is not flat in why we have a volatility smile so if you made it all the way through this video make sure you comment with what you learned or what you would add so that
